isol:world_region: Pacific Ocean region§gaz:00051073<§eco:0000313>Peter the Great Gulf§gaz:00007659
proj:comments: We measured growth under 24 different conditions for 85 accessions of Psychrobacter in tandem with whole genome sequencing and animal studies. We conducted comparative (phylo)genomics for these 85 Psychrobacter strains, as well as family-level comparative phylo-genomics. Our results indicate that growth at 37C is likely ancestral for the genus and is likely necessary for growth within mammalian bodies. Furthermore, Psychrobacter's closest relatives are pathobionts, and Psychrobacter likely evolved from a pathobiont ancestor.
seq:center: Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology

isol:isolation_source: In this study, we isolate and report the draft genome sequences of 14 bacterial strains from the marine sponge Spongia sp. using R2A and VXA media.<§eco:0000312>§https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.03.20.000216v1.full.pdf
isol:project_name: Genome of bacteria isolated from Sponge on R2A and VXA media.
proj:comments: Investigating sponge microbial symbionts is an important part of marine microbial ecology due to the ecological and biotechnological value of these dense and diverse microbial communities. Sponge-associated bacteria are involved in nutritional exchange with their hosts and are considered to play important roles in benthic biogeochemical cycling, and producing most of the secondary metabolite repertoire of sponges. Therefore, our understanding of the contribution of cultivable sponge-associated bacteria can provide better prespectives through this subject. This is a reason why we here describe 15 isolated bacteria genomes retrieved from Spongia sp., an iconic sponge species using 1/10R2A and VXA media.
seq:center: Station Biologique de Roscoff (CNRS - Sorbonne University)

proj:comments: V. nigripulchritudo is responsible for mass mortalities of shrimp in New Caledonia. The analysis of the genome sequence of one strain; SFn1 (realized by the Genoscope); genetic approaches and molecular epidemiology led us to suggest that plasmids and chromosomal elements played a role in the emergence of a pathogenic lineage. Through genome sequencing of 15 additional strains this project will yield insight into the key features underlying virulence; and will investigate whether horizontal gene acquisitions have driven the differentiation of virulent lineages.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolate from the green algae Acrosiphonia sonderi
proj:comments: In recent years; representatives of the Bacteroidetes have been increasingly recognized as specialists for the degradation of macromolecules. Formosa constitutes a Bacteroidetes genus within the class Flavobacteria; whose members have been found in marine habitats with high levels of organic matter; such as in association with algae; invertebrates and fecal pellets. Here we report on the generation and analysis of the genome of the Formosa agariphila type strain KMM 3901T ‚Äì an isolate from the green algae Acrosiphonia sonderi. F.¬†agariphila is a facultative anaerobe with the capacity for mixed acid fermentation and denitrification. Its genome harbors 129 proteases and 88 glycoside hydrolases; indicating a pronounced specialization on the degradation of proteins; polysaccharides and glycoproteins. 65 of the glycoside hydrolases are organized in at least 13 distinct polysaccharide utilization loci; where they are clustered with TonB-dependent receptors; SusD-like proteins; sensors/transcription factors; transporters and oftentimes sulfatases. These loci play a pivotal role in bacteroidetal polysaccharide biodegradation; and in the case of F.¬†agariphila revealed the capacity to degrade a wide range of algal polysaccharide from green; red and brown algae and thus a strong adaption towards an algae-associated lifestyle.

proj:comments: Photobacterium profundum strain SS9.This is the type strain for the species. It was isolated at a depth of 2500 m from the Sulu Trough. The genome contains 15 rRNA operons; the majority of which are on chromosome 1. There are 2 ATP synthase operons; one on each chromosome. Chromosome 1 contains more conserved genes; while chromosome 2 contains a large proportion of unique genes. High-pressure adaption has been studied by microarray analysis (ArrayExpress - E-MEXP-210).

isol:isolation_comments: This strain was isolated from sea water taken at a depth of 15 meters from the Mediterranean Sea
proj:comments: Synechococcus sp. strain RCC307. This strain was isolated from sea water taken at a depth of 15 meters from the Mediterranean Sea and will be used for comparative genomics Marine Synechococcus and Prochlorococcus are the most abundant photosynthetic organisms on earth and between them account for about half of the world's photosynthesis. RCC307 is an oceanic Synechococcus strain which presents great phylogenetic interest because trees obtained using its 16S RNA gene seem to indicate that it is rooted at the base of the radiation of marine cyanobacteria (adapted from http://www.genoscope.fr/externe/English/Projets/Projet_HP/organisme_HP.html).

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated together from fish with winter ulcer
proj:comments: Aliivibrio wodanis and Moritella viscosa have often been isolated together from fish with winter ulcer. Little is known about the interaction between the two bacterial species and how the presence of one bacterial species affects the behaviour of the other. The impact on bacterial growth in co-culture was investigated in vitro; and the presence of A. wodanis has a strong inhibitorial effect on M. viscosa. Further; we have sequenced the complete genomes of these two marine Gram-negative species; and have performed transcriptome analysis of the bacterial gene expression levels from in vivo samples. Using bacterial implants in the fish abdomen; we demonstrate that the presence of A. wodanis is altering the gene expression levels of M. viscosa compared to when the bacteria are implanted separately. The impeding effect on growth and the change in the global gene expression pattern of M. viscosa when the two pathogens co-exists is discussed in this paper.

proj:comments: Haloquadratum walsbyi C23. The type strain of Haloquadratum walsbyi; a square organism that dominates hypersaline waters. H.walsbyi is the first archaea identified that is probably able to synthesize sialic acid. These modifications, along with the potential capacity to synthesize and poly-gamma-glutamate capsule, probably create an aqueous shield and in the case of the capsule may also help maintain the unique shape of the cell. C23 is the type strain for the species, and was isolated from an Australian solar saltern.

isol:isolation_comments: Deep-sea wood falls
proj:comments: Desulfovibrio piezophilus sp. nov. C1TLV30 is able to grow up to 20 MPa. We aim to identifying genomic specificities for adaptation to high pressure by comparing this genome to that of D. vulgaris and using genomics data to identify differentially expressed proteins according to pressure growth conditions. A novel sulfate-reducing bacterium, designated C1TLV30(T), was isolated from wood falls at a depth of 1693 m in the Mediterranean Sea. Cells were motile vibrios (2-4 × 0.5 µm). Strain C1TLV30(T) grew at temperatures between 15 and 45 °C (optimum 30 °C) and at pH 5.4-8.6 (optimum 7.3). It required NaCl for growth (optimum at 25 g NaCl l(-1)) and tolerated up to 80 g NaCl l(-1). Strain C1TLV30(T) used as energy sources: lactate, fumarate, formate, malate, pyruvate and ethanol. The end products from lactate oxidation were acetate, H(2)S and CO(2) in the presence of sulfate as terminal electron acceptor. Besides sulfate, thiosulfate and sulfite were also used as terminal electron acceptors, but not elemental sulfur, fumarate, nitrate or nitrite. Strain C1TLV30(T) possessed desulfoviridin and was piezophilic, growing optimally at 10 MPa (range 0-30 MPa).

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from a deep-sea hydrothermal chimney sample collected at 13 N on the East-Pacific Rise at a depth of 2600 m. D. hydrothermalis is piezophilic; having an optimal growth at 25 MPa
proj:comments: Desulfovibrio hydrothermalis AM13T is a mesophilic; hydrogenotrophic; sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from a deep-sea hydrothermal chimney sample collected at 13¬ø¬ø N on the East-Pacific Rise at a depth of 2600 m. D. hydrothermalis is piezophilic; having an optimal growth at 25 MPa. Here we report the complete genome sequence of strain AM13; the type strain of D. hydrothermalis. The genome sequence is 3;702;934 bp lengh; with a G+C content of 45;14%. Moreover; the genome includes a circular plasmid of 5;328 bp. The genome reveals a view of the adaptation strategy to life in the depth in Desulfovibrio.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated fromhypersaline habitats and thus might explain why Halorhabdi have been found in such habitats worldwide
proj:comments: Background: Members of the euryarchaeal genus Halorhabus have been found in various hypersaline habitats; but so far are represented by only two isolates: H. utahensis AX-2T; a facultative anaerobe from the shallow Great Salt Lake of Utah; and H. tiamatea SARL4BT; an almost obligate anaerobe from the Shaban deep-sea hypersaline anoxic lake in the Red Sea; whose ecology is not well understood. Results: Here we present the complete genome of H. tiamatea SARL4BT and elucidate its niche adaptations. H. tiamatea SARL4BT excels as a polysaccharide-degrader as it constitutes the archaeon with the as yet highest number of glycoside hydrolases. Even though H. tiamatea SARL4BT inhabits a temperate; light-less; anoxic environment; its genome encodes genes usually found in hyperthermophiles; light-dependent enzymes such as bacteriorhodopsin; and a complete aerobic redox chain. Proteome analyses showed a pronounced stress response to oxygen; but simultaneously indicated possible respiration; and furthermore demonstrated relevance of the glycoside hydrolases. We could furthermore identify a closely related Halorhabus member in the Mediterranean deep-sea halophilic anoxic lake Medee by metagenomics and fluorescence in situ hybridization. Conclusions: Comparative genomics with H. utahensis AX-2T suggests that H. tiamatea SARL4BT evolved from a thermophile inhabiting an oxic habitat in the photic zone. H. tiamatea SARL4BT seems to have specialized on the degradation of recalcitrant algae and seagrass hemicelluloses that reach the deep-sea. Identification of a closely related Halorhabus member in the Mediterranean supports genetic drift among seemingly isolated hypersaline habitats and thus might explain why Halorhabdi have been found in such habitats worldwide.

isol:project_name: Complete genomes of five Synechococcus strains isolated from the Chesapeake Bay during winter
proj:comments: Synechococcus has a ubiquitous distribution, and has the capability to adapt to nearly every aquatic environment. Many marine and coastal Synechococcus strains have been sequenced, but only recently have estuarine strains been completed. Synechococcus cells survive at very low temperatures, but little is known about how they survive brackish waters that are nearly 0 degrees C. Psychrotolerant, or cold adapted, Synechococcus were isolated between December, 2010 and February, 2011. Of these Chesapeake Bay winter isolates, four sequences were completed: CBW1002, CBW1004, CBW1006, and CBW1108.
seq:center: University of Maryland Center For Environmental Science

isol:isolation_comments: Associated with marine sponge, Sycon capricorn
isol:project_name: Whole genome sequencing of bacteria isolated from marine sponge
proj:comments: Sponges (Porifera) harbour a dense population of microorganisms forming a holobiome. Studying these holobiomes has lead to the discovery of many novel species, metabolic process and natural products. Despite the richness of these natural resources the microbiome of many sponges remain enigmatic. Bacteria from the model calcareous sponge, Sycon capricorn, were isolated, cultured and genomic DNA extracted. Whole genome sequencing, using both long and short read platforms, assembled complete genomes. The completeness of these assemblies and the elucidation of natural plasmids exemplifies the utility of hybrid assemblies. Mining these genome assemblies for metabolic pathways begins to define the role of these microorganisms in the sponge holobiome.
seq:center: The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research organisation

isol:isolation_comments: isolated from the East China Sea for the production of inhibitory substances against Aquatic pathogens, whose antimicrobial peptides exhibited antibacterial activity not only against Gram-positive bacteria but also against Gram-negative bacteria, especially Vibrio parahaemolyticus
proj:comments: We have screened a B. subtilis strain H19 isolated from the East China Sea for the production of inhibitory substances against Aquatic pathogens, whose antimicrobial peptides exhibited antibacterial activity not only against Gram-positive bacteria but also against Gram-negative bacteria, especially Vibrio parahaemolyticus.However, in order to predict gene sequences encoding antimicrobial peptides and further explore the pathogenic mechanism of B. subtilis strain H19 against pathogens, it is necessary to have a deeper understanding of the genetic background of the strains.

proj:comments: Vibrio strains are pervasive in aquatic environment, form pathogenic and symbiotic relationship with host, and trigger the settlement of Mytilus coruscus. Vibrio cyclitrophicus ECSMB14105 is obtained from natural biofilms and has been used as a model strain elucidating Vibrio roles in settlement, and health and disease of M. coruscus. our genome data provide significant datasets for better understanding the gene function of V. cyclitrophicus ECSMB14105 in mussel development and health.

isol:isolation_comments: derived dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP)
proj:comments: The genus Sulfitobacter has been found in various marine and hypersaline environments. Bacteria of this genus were found to be associated with marine microalgae by inducing cell death of algae and degrading of algae-derived dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP). Here we reported the complete genome sequence of strain Sulfitobacter sp. BSw21498 isolated from seawater of Kongsfjorden, an Arctic fjord in Svalbard.

proj:comments: For good reasons, most studies on bacteria rely on well-established model organisms. However, we were wondering if such model species sufficiently cover fundamental key aspects of the bacterial biology. To answer this question, we selected the barely studied conspicuous bacterial phylum Planctomycetes. We collected samples from diverse aquatic habitats around the globe and performed a diversity-driven deep-cultivation approach. In total, we obtained far more novel planctomycetal axenic cultures than are currently available in strain collections and sequenced and analysed their genomes.

proj:comments: Bacterial communication mostly relies on homoserine lactone molecules, while unknown species of the human microbiome employ N-acyl amino acids for cross-kingdom interaction with their host. Here we describe an unprecedented bacterium of the maverick phylum Planctomycetes which produces a novel type of N-acyl amino acids as quorum sensing signals.

isol:isolation_comments: isolated from a bottom marine sediments in Kraternaya Bay, Yankicha Island, Middle Kuriles of Russian Federation
proj:comments: Spirochaetes are free-living, animal and protist-associated bacteria that are mainly helically-shaped, Gram-negative and motile with a distinctive cellular organization. They are also widespread in sulfur-rich environments like seas and oceanic ecosystems with a high level of H2S. Oceanispirochaeta crateria K2 has been isolated from a bottom marine sediments in Kraternaya Bay, Yankicha Island, Middle Kuriles of Russian Federation. It has been deposited into DSMZ microbial collection under DSM16308T. Its complete sequence and full methylome were determined using Pacific Biosciences SMRT sequencing.

isol:isolation_source: coastal seawater collected at Woods Hole, MA
proj:comments: Synechococcus spp. are unicellular cyanobacteria that are globally distributed and are responsible for up to 16% of net primary production in the ocean. Significant proportions of marine Synechococcus communities can be lysed daily by viruses; nevertheless, studies have shown that Synechococcus can rapidly become resistant to co-occurring viruses. The goal of this project was to identify the genetic determinants that lead to viral-resistance in Synechococcus sp. WH8101. To obtain resistant isolates, long-term laboratory pairwise coevolution experiments were conducted using Synechococcus sp. WH8101 and three T4-like myoviruses (RIM8, RIM12, and RIM44). Here, the genome of the ancestral Synechococcus sp. WH8101 isolate was sequenced and assembled. This genome sequence will be used as a reference to identify genetic changes that occurred during the course of the coevolution experiments. This research was supported by the National Science Foundation (OCE-1332782 and OIA-1736030)

isol:collected_by: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
proj:comments: The Red Sea is the largest, warmest, most saline of the world's seas. In many ways it is a model for global warming effects on marine ecosystems. Synechococcus sp. RSCCF101 is a Red Sea picocyanobacterium adapted to very high intensity sunlight and high salinity. This project investigated the molecular basis of its robust physiology and adaptations to the harsh conditions of its environment. These data will increase our understanding of how Synechococcus adapts to these conditions and indicate routes of adaptation to sea warming world wide.

proj:comments: Whole genome sequencing of cultured novel Roseobacter isolates, Leisingera janus, originally obtained from marine biofilms near tubes of the serpulid polychaete Hydroides elegans (Marina del Rey, California). Single-species biofilms of environmental isolates belonging to the Roseobacter clade (Rhodobacteraceae), a widespread and diverse group of marine Alphaproteobacteria, are inducers of settlement and metamorphosis of H. elegans. Although critical for processes such as sustaining many marine fisheries and biofouling, it is currently unclear how bacteria stimulate invertebrate marine larvae metamorphosis.

isol:isolation_comments: is from a deep-sea bacterium, Hydrogenovibrio thermophilus JR-2, which has the ability to grow very quickly, despite having to make all of its biomolecules from CO2 while using compounds like poisonous hydrogen sulfide or other reduced sulfur compounds for energy
isol:world_region: Pacific Ocean region§gaz:00051073<§eco:0000313>Juan de Fuca Ridge§gaz:00002438
proj:comments: This genome sequence is from a deep-sea bacterium, Hydrogenovibrio thermophilus JR-2, which has the ability to grow very quickly, despite having to make all of its biomolecules from CO2 while using compounds like poisonous hydrogen sulfide or other reduced sulfur compounds for energy. It can grow quickly despite low CO2 concentrations, and we are interested in understanding the genetic underpinnings of this capability. Annotating this genome will facilitate our efforts in using mutagenesis experiments to identify genes conferring low-CO2 growth capability, as well as incorporating these studies into undergraduate curricula.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from deep ocean ecosystems
proj:comments: Four Desulfovibrio spp. that exhibit a piezophilic lifestyle have been isolated from deep ocean ecosystems. Here, we report the genome sequence of the piezophilic Desulfovibrio profundus strain 500-1, isolated from a deep marine sediment layer at 500 m depth under a water column of 1,000 m depth, in the Japan Sea. The genome includes a 4,168,905-bp circular chromosome and two plasmids of 42,836-bp and 6,167-bp. It is the first genomic sequence of a piezophilic sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from a deep marine sediment layer. Analysis of this sequence will be helpful in elucidating adaptation of sulfate-reducing bacteria to deep-sea habitats.

proj:comments: New biological insecticides with different mode of actions are needed in order to broaden the range of susceptibility and also to avoid mosquito resistance to presently used biologicals. In our work, we compared the toxicities of two Clostridium bifermentans mosquitocidal strains and Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis against Aedes aegypti, Anopheles gambiae and An. stephensi. In order to identify the toxic components, we sequenced the genome of the Cb mosquitocidal strains. Our sequencing data showed that Cb mosquitocidal strains contain a megaplasmid pClosMP, that has two toxin loci.

isol:isolation_comments: Intertidal sediment
proj:comments: Cells of Erythrobacter seohaensis strain SW-135 are rod-shaped (0.6–0.8×1.5–4.0 μm) and nonspore-forming. Colonies on MA (5 days, 30 °C) are smooth, glistening, circular, convex, orange–yellow in colour and 1.0–2.0 mm in diameter. Growth occurs at 10 and 40°C, but not at 4°C or above 41°C. Optimal pH for growth is 7.0–8.0; growth is observed at pH 5.5 but not at pH 5.0. Optimal growth occurs in the presence of 2–3%(w/v) NaCl; growth does not occur without NaCl or in the presence of>9% NaCl. The predominant respiratory lipoquinone is Q-10. The DNA G+C content is 62.2 mol % (determined by HPLC).
seq:center: Second Institute of Oceanography, State Oceanic Administration

proj:comments: The strain Streptomyces sp. isol:isolation_comments: Shipworm (Teredinidae) gill
proj:comments: Certain marine invertebrates harbor chemosynthetic bacterial symbionts, giving them the remarkable ability to consume inorganic chemicals such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S) rather than organic matter as food. These chemosynthetic animals are found near geochemical (e.g. hydrothermal vents) or biological (e.g. decaying wood or large animal carcasses) sources of H2S on the sea floor. Although many such symbioses have been discovered, little is known about how or where they originated. Here we demonstrate a new chemosynthetic symbiosis in the giant teredinid bivalve (shipworm) Kuphus polythalamia and show that this symbiosis arose in a wood-eating ancestor via the displacement of ancestral cellulolytic symbionts by sulfur-oxidizing invaders. Here wood served as an evolutionary stepping stone for a dramatic transition from heterotrophy to chemoautotrophy.

isol:isolation_source: Sea water from the Delaware coast
proj:comments: Pseudoalteromonas piscicida strain DE2-B is a naturally occurring, Gram-negative, marine Gammaproteobacterium that was isolated from sea water from the Delaware coast (USA). It produces antimicrobial compounds that have a broad spectrum of inhibitory activities against human and fish pathogens including vibrios. Pseudoalteromonas spp. have been used as probiotics to reduce pathogens in aquaculture and has been shown to reduce biofilm formation. In this study, we fully sequenced and annotated P. piscicida strain DE2-B to further elucidate the genome and to facilitate research on compounds that are inhibitory toward other Gram-negative as well as Gram-positive bacteria.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated in June of 2013 from AHPND-affected Litopenaeus vannamei in China and characterized by pirABvp positive
proj:comments: Acute hepatopancreatic necrosis disease (AHPND) is a severe shrimp disease that has caused heavy losses to the global shrimp farming industry. AHPND-causing Vibrio parahaemolyticus (VPAHPND) is almost the only known pathogen responsible for the disease. Rare cases of AHPND caused by Vibrio species other than V. parahaemolyticus were reported. Strain 20130629003S01 is the first reported V. campbellii isolate which can cause AHPND. This stain was isolated in June of 2013 from AHPND-affected Litopenaeus vannamei in China and characterized by pirABvp positive. Genome sequencing of 20130629003S01 can provide timely information for better understanding of genomic characteristics of pathogen.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from the oxic-anoxic transition zone of the Chesapeake Bay during seasonal stratification, these two chemolithoautotrophs produce bundles of iron-oxide dread structures, and are novel for their planktonic lifestyle
proj:comments: Zetaproteobacteria, a class of marine neutrophilic iron-oxidizing bacteria (FeOB), have recently begun to be recognized in coastal environments. Here we present the isolation and genomic analysis of two coastal Zetaproteobacteria, Mariprofundus micogutta strains CP-5 and CP-8. Isolated from the oxic-anoxic transition zone of the Chesapeake Bay during seasonal stratification, these two chemolithoautotrophs produce bundles of iron-oxide dread structures, and are novel for their planktonic lifestyle.

proj:comments: The non-axenic culture of Moorea producens PAL was sequenced by both short and long reads (Illumina MiSeq and PacBio RS II), which were assembled together using the software SPAdes 3.5. Besides the complete of M. producens PAL, our binning procedure identified a possibly fully assembled large linear contig of 3.63 Mb that represents a draft genome of a Hyphomonas sp. strain Mor2, an uncultured alpha-proteobacteria associated with M. producens PAL.

isol:isolation_source: Shallow tropical waters, normally from coral reef substrate
proj:comments: The strain Moorea producens JHB 22AUG96-1 (aka JHB) was collected from Hector Bay, Jamaica, in August of 1996. It was isolated as a mono-algal culture, although remained non-axenic due to the presence of associated heterotrophs (such as Acidobacteria bacterium Mor1, ASM166450v1). Moorea producens JHB was sequenced by Illumina HiSeq platform. In this project, we used a reference genome (Moorea producens PAL 15AUG08-1) to substantially improve the assembly of M. producens JHB.

isol:isolation_source: Shallow tropical waters, normally from coral reef substrate
proj:comments: Short and long reads (Illumina MiSeq and PacBio RS II) were assembled togetherusing standard settings of SPAdes 3.5, and yielded 47 linear contigs larger than 500 bp along with one circular contig of 35.5 kb (a cyanobacterial plasmid candidate). In order to resolve these regions and close the genome, we proceeded to long reads scaffolding by the software SSPACE-LongReads, standard settings. Fourteen of the contigs assembled into a single circular scaffold of 9.67 Mb, and gaps were closed using again the long reads. The minimum coverage was 98-fold, and together with the 35.5 kb circular plasmid, it constitutes the complete M. producens PAL 15AUG08-1 genome, the first complete genome of a filamentous marine tropical cyanobacterium. This cyanobacterium has an impressive 19.89 % of its genome is devoted to the production of secondary metabolites, four times the cyanobacterial average.

proj:comments: In this study we investigated key bacteria which have been identified as relevant polysaccharide degrader during marine phytoplankton blooms. By means of proteomic and genomic functional analyses of these marine bacteria of thephylum Bacteroidetes that are specialized on polysaccharide degradation. Physiological proteogenomics of cultivable environmentally relevant key bacteria under defined in vitro conditions will complement the in situ studies.In-depth biochemical characterizations of identified key proteins will be used to determine strategies of marine polysaccharide utilization and to unravel the specific ecophysiological roles of distinct bacterial populations during algal blooms.

proj:comments: Bacillus species Alg07 was isolated from marine area of Weihai City, Shandong Province, China. This strain showed extremely high extracellular activity towards alginate, and exhibited extraordinary metabolic ability to degrade brown algae. Notably, the phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences suggested that Alg07 might be a novel species within Bacillus genus. In order to elucidate the metabolic capability and ecological adaptation with respect to brown algae degradation, we have sequenced the complete genome of Bacillus weihaiensis Alg07.

isol:isolation_comments: Vibrio anguillarum strain MVAV6203 has been constructed from a wide-type V. anguillarum MVM425 with the curing of virulence-related plasmid pEIB1 and an unmarked gene deletion of the aroC
proj:comments: In this work, we sequenced the genome of V. anguillarum MVAV6203 by 454, Illumina Solexa method and splicing of PCR. The genome of V. anguillarum MVAV6203, with the GC content of 44.5 %, contains two chromosomes, the big one, termed as Chr1 is 3,097,087 bp and contains 2838 genes, the small one, termed as Chr2 is approximately 950 kb and encodes about 1000 genes. Genome sequence analysis indicated that Chr1 contains a number of the virulence related genes such as haemolysin, flagellin and out membrane protein. Most of the environmental adaptability genes like temperature stress, osmotic pressure and drug resistance are located on Chr2.V. anguillarum MVAV6203 chromosome 2 contains a super-integron with the length of about 60 kb and including 50~80 gene cassettes, most of the gene cassettes encode conservative hypothetical proteins. Several gene cassettes carry the genes related to Bleomycin resistance and RelBE Toxin-Antitoxin system which strengthen the stability of super-integron gene cassette array. Comparative genomics analysis demonstrated that V. anguillarum MVAV6203 has a close evolutionary relationship to Vibrio cholerae and Vibrio vulnificus, and simultaneously, its virulence regulation, pathogenic mechanism and drug resistance are similar to other vibrios strains. Comparative genomics analysis also determined 1895 important homologous proteins in vibrios.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from deep sea water
proj:comments: Dissolved organic matter (DOM) in the ocean is the fundamental part of marine carbon biogeochemical cycles. The DOM pool is the largest organic carbon pool in the ocean. Exopolysaccharides (EPS) produced by marine bacteria are high molecular weight carbohydrate polymers, and it constitutes a large fraction of the total DOM in the sea. Meanwhile, EPS plays an important role in the material and energy cycle in the ocean. However, the significance of bacterial EPS in marine environments is not clearly understood, as not much is known about the contribution of bacterial EPS to the DOM pool and its bioavailability. Additionally, the current insights of EPS production are limited to microorganisms isolated from terrestrial environment and only a few studies have reported the EPS-producing bacteria which were retrieved from typical marine environments. So the strain Phaeobacter gallaeciensis JL2886 as EPS-producing bacteria in South China Sea was isolated and it as the type strain of deep sea EPS produced strain was sequenced for further research.

proj:comments: V.vulnificus strain CECT4999 is an isolate of biotype 2 (BT2) serovar E from Spain. As an eel pathogen, serovar E causes primary septicemia or vibriosis that affects captured eels maintained in breeding farms. The aim of this study is to sequence and annotate the BT2 genome and to perform a comparative analysis among BT1 and BT2 strains to identify possible virulence mechanisms in the V. vulnificus genome.

isol:isolation_comments: isolated from black mud of the San Francisco Bay
proj:comments: Clostridium propionicumwas isolated from black mud of the San Francisco Bay. The strictly anaerobic bacterium thrives on the fermentation of single amino acids:alpha- and beta-alanineas well as serinelead to ammonia, acetate, CO2 and propionate. With threonine propionate and butyrate are formed. The pathway of alanine reduction to propionate proceeds via acryloyl-CoA and not via succinate as in Propionibacterium species.

proj:comments: Colwellia sp. MT41. Colwellia sp. MT41 was isolated from a deep sea crustacean; Hirondellea gigas; obtained from the Marianas Trench at a depth of 10;476 meters. This organism is an obligate barophile with optimum growth being seen at 690 bars (6.9 x 107 Pa) at 2oC. No growth was seen at pressures below 380 bars. This organism is one of the most barophilic organisms that has been isolated and will provide information on the adaptations necessary for life under extreme pressure.

proj:comments: Halite endoliths (salt rocks) in the Atacama Desert represent one of the most extreme environments on Earth. We obtained a 9.6 Gb high quality shotgun metagenome from halite nodules collected in the Salar Grande area. Our metagenome is unique because it has high sequencing depth, low diversity, and representative members from all 3 domains of life and from viruses. Taxonomic assignment of the metagenomic reads confirmed that the community is dominated by members of the Archaea, including Nanohaloarchaea, and also comprised members of the Bacteria and Eukarya. The functional annotation of the metagenome revealed that the cyanobacterium Halothece might be responsible for most of the CO2 fixed in the community and that a number of archaea and bacteria could carry out photoheterotrophy, via light-driven proton pumps, increasing the energy budget of the community from light. Our analysis predicted that the alga identified in the community has one of the lowest protein isoelectric point (pI) distributions of any reported eukaryote. Its pI profile was similar to that of halophiles using a “salt-in” strategy. Our genome assembly produced a nanohaloarchaeon genome of 1.2 Mbp with Candidatus Haloredivivus as the closest known reference. We have named this new microorganism Candidatus Nanopetramus SG9. Analysis of its genome sequence revealed a photoheterotrophic life style, a low median isoelectric point for all its predicted proteins, suggesting a “salt-in” strategist, and the presence of a unique CRISPR/Cas system in its genome; one of the spacers from this unique CRISPR/Cas system matched a partial viral genome from the metagenome. We developed new methods to identify viral genomic content from metagenome data, resulting in the identification of over 30 complete or near complete viral or proviral genomes in the halite metagenome. These viral genomes were diverse in genome structure, gene content, host, and genome size. Putative hosts for these viruses included Halobacteriaceae, Nanohaloarchaea, and Cyanobacteria. Despite the dependence on deliquescence of the halite community for liquid water availability, this study revealed an ecosystem spanning three phylogenetic domains, containing a large diversity of viruses, and a predominant “salt-in” strategy to balance the high osmotic pressure of the environment.

isol:isolation_comments: Derived from algal, plants, or animals, through the action of the extracellular enzyme systems or surface-associated enzyme complexes
proj:comments: Flammeovirga sp. MY04 is an agar-liquefying marine bacterium with versatile polysaccharide-degrading abilities. It potently degrades multiple carbohydrates derived from algal, plants, or animals, through the action of the extracellular enzyme systems or surface-associated enzyme complexes. This organism may be useful in bioremediation. The abundant agarase system contains agarases from the families of GH16, GH50, and GH86. The extracellular agarases are stable in a wide range of temperatures, pH values, and NaCl concentrations, and digest agarose into neoagaro-oligosaccharides efficiently. The GH16 modules of surface-associated-agarases contain novel inner peptides that are essential for the enzyme to divide neoagarooctaose into neoagarotetraose.

isol:isolation_comments: Origin of samples, enrichments and cultivation conditions. The top 10 cm layer of sediment cores and brine samples were collected from several hypersaline chloride-sulfate lakes located in the Kulunda Steppe (southwestern Siberia, Altai region, Russia) (Sorokin et al., 2012). Superficial anoxic sediments were also collected from sulfidic hypersaline lake Lagoona Fuente de Piedra (coordinates: 37°05.717N; 04°47.483E, Malaga, Spain) and from the deep-sea hypersaline lake Medee (coordinates: 34°26.250N; 22°19.783E, Ionian Sea, Eastern Mediterranean, 3105 m below sea level) (Yakimov et al., 2013). The mineral medium used for enrichment and further cultivation of extremely halophilic sulfur reducers contained the following (g l−1): 240 NaCl; 3 K2HPO4; 0.5 NH4Cl; 10 HEPES. The pH was adjusted to 7.0 by 1 M KOH. After sterilization, the medium was supplemented with 5 mmol l−1 MgCl2 × 6H2O, 1 ml l−1 of trace metal solution (Pfennig and Lippert, 1966) and 10 mg l−1 of yeast extract. Elemental sulfur flour was sterilized at 110 °C for 30 min as a wet paste and added to approximately 2 g l−1. Cultivation was performed in serum bottles with butyl rubber stoppers. The medium was made anoxic first by ‘cold boiling’ upon evacuation followed by three cycles of flushing with argon and evacuation. Anaerobic conditions were achieved by the final addition of 0.2 mmol l−1 HS−. After five cycles of evacuation-flushing, the residual HS− concentration in the medium was less than 5 μmol l−1. The cultures were incubated at 30–37 °C with periodic shaking.
proj:comments: An obligatory anaerobic haloarchaea growing by dissimilatory sulfur reduction.

proj:comments: The OM43 Clade encompasses bacteria that oxidize methanol for energy and growth. Only two marine isolates exist to date from the Oregon coast (HTCC8121) and Hawaii (KB13) but no description has been made from the Red Sea; which is more ultra-oligotrophic; and experiences conditions representing a worst-case-scenario for global warming oceans. The comparison of OM43 strains provides a better understanding of their biogeography and ecological roles in disparate marine provinces of the global ocean.
secmet:antismash_types: Putative fatty acid cluster|Putative fatty acid cluster|Putative cluster|Putative saccharide cluster|Ectoine cluster|Terpene cluster
seq:center: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST)

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from marine sponges Antho dichotoma (isolate ADI127-17) and Geodia barretti (GBA129-24) collected at the Trondheim fjord (Norway)
proj:comments: Two actinomycete bacteria whose 16S rRNA gene displayed>99% identity to the type strain of Actinoalloteichus hymeniacidonis have been isolated from marine sponges Antho dichotoma (isolate ADI127-17) and Geodia barretti (GBA129-24) collected at the Trondheim fjord (Norway). Despite high level of identity on the 16S rRNA gene level, the new isolates differed from A. hymeniacidonics morphologically, and by requirement for sea water for growth. The project intends to compare genomes of the new isolates with that of A. hymeniacidonis, and to unravel unique genome features and biosynthetic potential of the three organisms.

isol:isolation_comments: Sea water was collected in the Northern Adriatic Sea from approx. 0.5 m depth off Piran, Slovenia (45.518 N, 13.568 E) in two consecutive months (November and December 2011). At the time of sampling, sea water temperatures ranged between 13.1 and 15.5 °C and ammonium concentrations varied between 0.12 and 0.48 μm.
proj:comments: Candidatus Nitrosopumilus piranensis D3C was isolated from coastal surface water of the northern Adriatic Sea (approx. 0.5 m depth) off the coast of Piran; Slovenia; in December 2011. They can oxidize ammonia into nitrite and fix inorganic carbon via the 3-hydroxypropionate/4-hydroxybutyrate cycle and are able to utilize urea as an alternative substrate. Genome size is 1.71-Mb. env_temp: 13.1-15.5

isol:isolation_comments: A hyperthermophilic sulfate reducer, strain 7324, was isolated from hot (75°C) oil field waters from an oil production platform in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea. It was enriched on a complex medium and isolated on lactate with sulfate. The cells were nonmotile, irregular coccoid to disc shaped, and 0.3 to 1.0 μm wide. The temperature for growth was between 60 and 85°C with an optimum of 76°C. Lactate, pyruvate, and valerate plus H2 were utilized as carbon and energy sources with sulfate as electron acceptor.
proj:comments: Genome of sulfate reducing bacterium Archaeoglobus fulgidus 7324; DSM 8774 isolated from marine oilfields in the North sea.

proj:comments: Complete Genome Sequence of Hyperthermophilic Palaeococcus pacificus DY20341T; Isolated from a Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Sediments. Palaeococcus pacificus strain DY20341 was isolated from a sediments sample collected from a hydrothermal vent area in East Pacific Ocean at a depth of 2;737 m in 2008(REF). Palaeococcus pacificus is a piezophilicÔºåhyperthermolphilicÔºåsulfur-reducing heterotrophic archaeon belonging to the order Thermococcales (encompassing the genera Thermococcus; Pyrococcus; and Palaeococcus) and is a hyperthermophile growing at temperatures ranging from 50C to 90¬∞C (optimaly at 80¬∞C) and a piezophile growing optimally under 30 MPa. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences showed that it was most closely related to Pa. ferrophilus; with a similarity of 95.7%.

In 1974, a new species named Clostridium durum was described by Smith and Cat0 (1 1) as the dominant organism in a sediment core from the Black Sea. All of the isolates in this study formed a homogeneous group and had similar properties, and strain VPI 6563 was deposited as the type strain in the American Type Culture Collection as strain ATCC 27763

proj:comments: Vibrio tubiashii is the cause of bacillary necrosis in larval shellfish. It is a naturally occurring; Gram-negative; marine bacterium that has long been associated with high mortalities of larval shellfish and significant economic losses in shellfish hatcheries. High mortalities in larval oyster and clam production facilities have been associated with contamination by V. tubiashii and have led to reductions in the availability of seed oysters and clams needed for commercial shellfish planting.

proj:comments: Vibrio coralliilyticus is a Gram-negative marine bacterium that is reported to cause coral bleaching; which has destroyed coral reefs worldwide. It is also pathogenic to larval shellfish and is likely responsible for major mortalities in shellfish hatcheries and potentially in natural settings. It has been confused with Vibrio tubiashii; a related species also known to cause larval shellfish mortalities. Some marine isolates thought to be V. tubiashii (like RE22 and the American Type Culture Collection strain ATCC 19105) have been reclassified as V. coralliilyticus. Strain RE98; until now thought to be a V. tubiashii; is particularly virulent toward larval oysters and was identified here by complete genome sequencing as V. coralliilyticus. The misidentification of several V. coralliilyticus as V. tubiashii has complicated the discernment of the roles of these pathogens as agents of larval shellfish mortalities and in coral bleaching. Complete sequencing and annotation of V. coralliilyticus RE98 and its plasmids provides valuable information for the study of its virulence; antibiotic resistance; and inactivation. Host_age: Larvae

isol:isolation_comments: A conditional piezophilic, hyperthermophilic archaeon showing growth over a wide range of temperature, pH and pressure was isolated from an oil-immersed hydrothermal chimney at a depth of 2006.9 m in the Guaymas Basin. Enrichment and isolation of strain A501(T) were performed at 80 °C at 0.1 MPa. Cells of isolate A501(T) were irregular motile cocci with a polar tuft of flagella and generally 0.6-2.6 µm in diameter. Growth was detected over the range 50-100 °C (optimal growth at 85 °C) at atmospheric pressure and was observed at 102 °C at a pressure of 10 MPa. At 85 °C, growth was observed at a pressure of 0.1-70 MPa (optimum pressure 0.1 MPa-30 MPa), while at 95 °C, the pressure allowing growth ranged from 0.1 MPa to 50 MPa (optimum pressure 10 MPa). Cells of strain A501(T) grew at pH 4-9 (optimum pH 7.0) and a NaCl concentration of 1.0-5.0 % (w:v) (optimum concentration 2.5 % NaCl).
proj:comments: Thermococcus sp. A501 Genome sequencing; hydrothermal vent

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from rearings and collectors of the scallop Pecten maximus (in Galicia; Spain); and M. algicola; which was isolated from a stationary culture of the toxin-producing marine dinoflagellate Prorocentrum lima (in Vigo; Spain)
proj:comments: Members of the Phaeobacter-Leisingera-Marinovum cluster are physiologically highly diverse. Overall they are able to use a large variety of substrates; produce several secondary metabolites and signalling molecules; and form biofilms. While Phaeobacter spp. have very broad substrate spectra; Leisingera spp. are methylotrophic; i.e. they can grow on a very limited number of methylated substrates. This indicates a specific adaptation which is probably reflected in the genome; possibly by loss of genes coding for specific metabolic pathways.The strains proposed to be sequenced originate from diverse marine habitats (mostly natural surfaces) from all over the world; i.e. tidal flats of the North Sea and the Yellow Sea; marine sediments of the Arctic Ocean and the South China Sea; from a marine electroactive biofilm exposed to natural sea water taken at Genoa; Italy; and from sea water collected from a tide pool off the coast of central California. Some strains of this cluster were found to be associated with higher organisms; such as P. gallaeciensis; which was isolated from rearings and collectors of the scallop Pecten maximus (in Galicia; Spain); and M. algicola; which was isolated from a stationary culture of the toxin-producing marine dinoflagellate Prorocentrum lima (in Vigo; Spain). While most organisms of this group are mesophilic; P. arcticus is a psychrophile.The already sequenced Phaeobacter genomes contain several plasmids which encode genes involved in specific adaptations such as secondary metabolism and biofilm formation. The genome of M. algicola comprises the highest number (10) of plasmids found within the Roseobacter clade. Preliminary experiments (pulsed field gel electrophoresis) with some of the organisms proposed to be sequenced showed that these also contain several plasmids of different size. For P. inhibens and P. daeponensis we detected five plasmids in each organism; while for L. methylohalidivorans only one plasmid was found.

proj:comments: The genus Alteromonas contains species of marine bacteria that have been isolated often from the oceans around the world. Based on the phylogenetic analysis of 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities; strain DE170 was classified as another member of the genus Alteromonas with 99% of 16S rRNA gene sequence identity to the recently described Alteromonas australica H 17T(Ivanova et al; 2013). This study aimed to provide a detailed genomic investigation of the two A. australica strains obtained from two geographically distant locations.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated on February 1988 from marine sediments of Barcelona coast (Spain) using 2-methylnaphthalene as unique carbon and energy source
proj:comments: Pseudomonas stutzeri 19SMN4 (= DSM 6084) is the reference strain of the genomovar 4 of its species. It is a benzoate-; naphthalene- and salicylate-degrading bacterium that was isolated on February 1988 from marine sediments of Barcelona coast (Spain) using 2-methylnaphthalene as unique carbon and energy source. Naphthalene degradation pathway is plasmid encoded. Naphthalene degradation proceeds via salicylate and catechol; being this last compound channeled to TCA by meta-cleavage.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated on ONR7, a medium with alkanes and cannot grow on other substrates
proj:comments: Thalassolituus oleivorans is a highly specialized marine hydrocarbonoclastic bacteria, a predominant hydrocarbon degrader from polluted sites in Barents sea. Thalassolituus strains make up from 10 to 30 % from total number of culturable oil-degrading bacteria. These bacteria are easily isolated on ONR7, a medium with alkanes and cannot grow on other substrates. This strain was isolated by Novikov A and Shatalov A, during Barents sea expedition.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from the light organs of the squid Euprymna scolopes
proj:comments: Vibrio fischeri strain ES114. This strain was isolated from the light organs of the squid Euprymna scolopes. Interestingly; the genome encodes a cholera toxin phage-like element on chromosome II. However; the cluster of genes responsible for phage excision is missing; and the two CTS genes have been replaces. There are also a number of pilus synthesis genes present in the genome; which may function during symbiosis. Comparison of the genome from this organism and the pathogenic Vibrio spp. will shed light on both the virulence as well as symbiosis-establishing mechanisms.

isol:isolation_comments: Here we announce the complete genome sequence of V. parahaemolyticus BB22OP, a Bangladesh environmental isolate from the early 1980s (9). This strain, with an O4:K8 serotype, has been extensively studied with respect to swimming and swarming motility, biofilm development, and phase variation.
proj:comments: Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a foodborne pathogen that is a major worldwide cause of gastroenteritis. Here we report the complete; annotated genome of the prepandemic V. parahaemolyticus strain BB22OP that has been extensively studied for its motility; quorum sensing; and phenotypic switch between opaque (OP) and translucent (TR) phenotypes.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from a geothermal marine area near Vulcano; Italy
isol:isolation_source: Geothermal marine area near Vulcano; Italy
proj:comments: Thermotoga maritima strain MSB8. This hyperthermophilic organism was originally isolated from a geothermal marine area near Vulcano; Italy. Strain MSB8 is the type strain. It is representative of a very deep branch of eubacteria and a very large portion of the genome; 24% of all ORFs; is similar to archaeal genes; suggesting horizontal gene transfer; a hypothesis supported by the fact that many regions of the chromosome containing these genes have a significantly different composition as compared to the rest of the genome. This organism appears to live in a rich environment as it encodes a large number of transporters; both for import and export; of complex substrates such as carbohydrates; including a type II secretion system that may be used to export extracellular enzymes for degradation of biopolymers.

Doubling time is four hours under optimal conditions. The organism is an autotrophic or organotrophic sulfate/sulfite respirer. An additional distinguishing characteristic is blue-green fluorescence at 420 nm.

isol:isolation_comments: A water sample was collected in a 2-l Niskin bottle fitted with a Teflon-coated spring from a depth of 10 m at a station 27.6 km off of the coast of Oregon on the Newport Hydrographic line (44° 39.1' N, 124° 24.7' W).
proj:comments: Pelagibacter ubique strain HTCC1062. This organism is used in comparative genomics. The chromosome encodes biosynthetic pathways for all twenty amino acids and many enzymatic cofactors. There appears to be no recently horizontally transferred DNA in this organism and it does not even contain transposable elements although it does encode DNA uptake genes. The bacterium can generate energy through a light-driven proteorhodopsin proton pump or via respiration. Many metabolic pathways; including the Entner-Duodoroff; TCA; and glyoxylate bypass are present. This organism also encodes genes for type II secretion and type IV pilus synthesis.

isol:isolation_comments: Aeromonas salmonicida (strain A449) was isolated from a brown trout in the Eure River, France in 1975 and harbors one chromosome and 5 plasmids. Comparison to the related A.hydrophilia ATCC 7966 (AERHH) show the presence of numerous insertion sequence, some of which are still active and various other mobile elements lreading to substantial genome rearrangements. A.salmonicida is no longer mobile and has also recently lost a type IV and type VI secretion systems, thus probably avoiding the host immune system. It seems to be undergoing genome decay and adaptation to its specific host (adapted from PMID 18801193).

proj:comments: Pseudomonas stutzeri CCUG 29253 (P. stutzeri AN10) is a well characterized naphthalene degrading bacterium isolated from sediments of the West Mediterranean Sea. Although it is able to grow with naphthalene and/or salicylate as unique carbon and energy source; salicylate seem to be toxic for strain AN10 at concentrations higher than 3 mM. proj:comments: Haloferax mediterranei is an extreme halophilic archaeon with many biotechnological applications. Its carbon and nitrogen metabolism is well known. It has been described as a denitrifying microorganism able to grow with nitrite as the sole nitrogen source for growth in an assimilatory process under aerobic conditions. This haloarchaeon can also reduce nitrite in a respiratory process; where nitrite is the electron acceptor when oxygen conditions are limited.

proj:comments: Methanopyrus kandleri AV19. This organism is an obligately anaerobic hyperthermophilic archeon that was isolated from Guaymas hot vents in anaerobic sea water at a depth of 2000 m. The M. kandleri AV19 genome analysis reveals that this organism is a "minimalist" archaeon; with a small number of genes transferred from bacteria; low diversity of transporters; and particularly; an under representation of predicted regulatory proteins. The presence of such minimal gene set may be a reflection of the M. kandleri's extreme habitat; which could limit its ability to exchange genes with other organisms.

isol:project_name: Candidatus Nitrosopumilus koreensis AR1
proj:comments: Draft genome sequence of the ammonia-oxidizing archaeon "Candidatus Nitrosopumilus koreensis" AR1 from Arctic Some lineages of Thaumarchaeota inhabiting various environments, including marine water, freshwater, and hot springs, have been proposed for use as ammonia-oxidizing archaea (AOA) (5, 9, 11). These microbes are capable of using ammonia as an energy source and of performing carbon fixation through the 3-hydroxypropionate/4-hydroxybutyrate pathway (1). But, despite their important contributions to the biogeochemical nitrogen cycle, there remain many unanswered questions on their physiology and ecology. Recently, the genome sequence of “Candidatus Nitrosopumilus maritimus” strain SCM1, an ammonia-oxidizing archaeon initially isolated in an aquarium. More recently still, AOA in 78-m-deep marine sediment off Svalbard, the Arctic Circle, were enriched using ammonia as an electron donor (8). One such AOA was identified as “Candidatus Nitrosopumilus koreensis” strain AR1, the genome of which was analyzed in the present study.

isol:isolation_comments: This strain was isolated from Pacific Ocean marine sediments at a depth of 630 m.
proj:comments: Shewanella sp. W3-18-1. This strain was isolated from Pacific Ocean marine sediments at a depth of 630 m. Shewanella are facultatively anaerobic, Gram-negative bacteria, motile by polar flagella, rod-like, and generally associated with aquatic or marine environments. . They are capable of using a variety of compounds as electron acceptors, including oxygen, iron, manganese, uranium, nitrate, nitrite, fumarate, to name but a few. This ability makes Shewanella important for bioremediation of contaminated metals and radioactive wastes. The genus Shewanella comprises 36 recognized and hundreds of uncharacterized cultivable species.

isol:isolation_source: Head of an oil-producing well on the offshore oil/gas platform near the coastal town of Vung Tau in southern Vietnam.
proj:comments: Marinobacter aquaeolei VT8. Marinobacter aquaeolei VT8; also known as Marinobacter hydrocarbonoclasticus VT8; is a moderately halophilic; hydrocarbon-degrading bacterium isolated from an oil well off the coast of Vietnam. Marinobacter aquaeolei is also able to oxidize iron. The availability of iron is considered important to the cycling of carbon in the ocean and iron deficiency is believed to limit primary productivity. Marinobacter aquaeolei; as well as other members of this genus; may play a significant role in the iron and carbon cycles in the marine environment. This organism will be used for comparative genomics.

isol:isolation_source: Culture of the dinoflagellate Pfiesteria piscicida CCMP1830
proj:comments: Ruegeria sp. TM1040. This strain was isolated from a culture of the dinoflagellate Pfiesteria piscicida CCMP1830 which has been implicated in many large scale algal blooms resulting in increased mortality in fish. The bacteria are attached to the surface of the dinoflagellate and in some ways allow the dinoflagellate to grow as those lacking the bacteria die off. The bacterium also chemotaxes towards the dinoflagellate product DMSP (dimethylsulfoniopropionate) and metabolizes it. DMSP is a major source of sulfur in marine ecosystems and plays a role in the sulfur biogeochemical cycle. The implication is a tight association between these important dinoflagellates and this marine bacterium.

isol:isolation_comments: A water sample (5 liters) from the Kabeltonne site at Helgoland Roads in the North Sea (54°11.18′N, 7°54′E) was collected at a depth of 0.5 m in September 2006 and processed immediately at the Biological Station of Helgoland. The water sample was filtered first through a 10-μm-pore-size filter and then through a 0.2-μm-pore-size filter. Total DNA was extracted from the 0.2-μm filter with the FastDNA Spin kit for soil (Qbiogene) and used for the clone library. An aliquot (10 ml) of the filtrate from the 10-μm filter was removed and immediately used for isolation of bacteria
proj:comments: Comparitive genome analysis.

proj:comments: A total of 74 actinomycete isolates were cultivated from two marine sponge species; Geodia barretti and Phakellia ventilabrum collected at the same spot at the bottom of the Trondheim fjord (Norway). Phylogenetic analyses of sponge-associated actinomycetes based on the 16S rRNA gene sequences demonstrated the presence of species belonging to the genera Streptomyces; Nocardiopsis; Rhodococcus; Pseudonocardia and Micromonospora. Most of the isolates required sea water for growth; suggesting them being adapted to the marine environment. Phylogenetic analysis of Streptomyces spp. revealed two isolates originating from different sponges and having 99.7 % identity in their 16S rRNA gene sequences; suggesting that they might represent very closely related strains. Draft sequencing; annotation; and analysis of the genomes of these Streptomyces isolates clearly indicated that they had a common terrestrial ancestor; Streptomyces albus. Targeted analysis of the secondary metabolite biosynthesis genes in two genomes suggested recent acquisition of the gene cluster for enterocin by both isolates. Despite overall high similarity of the housekeeping genes in the two studied Streptomyces isolates and S. albus; certain secondary metabolite biosynthesis genes were shown to be differentially acquired or lost; supporting the hypothesis of divergent evolution in two sponge species.

proj:comments: Synechococcus sp. WH 8109. Synechococcus sp. WH 8109 was isolated from the Sargasso Sea. This strain is a member of marine cluster A; Clade II (Rocap et al. 2002; Fuller et al. 2003). Clade II Synechococcus types are an important component of the phytoplankton; being commonly detected in environmental clone libraries (Ahlgren and Rocap 2007; Penno et al. 2006) and being the dominant Synechococcus group in many oceanic regimes (Fuller et al. 2006; Fuller et al. 2005; Zwirglmaier et al. 2007).

isol:isolation_source: Brain tissue from host Stenella coeruleoalba
proj:comments: Brucella ceti has been reported as the etiological agent of several chronic diseases in cetaceans. B.ceti isolates; even if belonging to the same specie; present distinct genetic traits and host preferences. In 2012; several Stenella coeruleoalba animals have been found dead on Adriatic Sea costs. Post mortem analysis revealed the presence of the B.ceti in their brain tissue. The aim of the study is the deep characterization of the isolates to clarify genetic relationship with already described B.ceti types: porpoise; dolphins and human types; since they display variable virulence and infectivity in hosts; including humans.

isol:isolation_comments: Brackish pond
proj:comments: One of the purple sulfur bacteria, Thiocystis violascens, formerly known as Chromatium violascens, is a motile, 2.0 um spherical cell first described in 1852. It contains internal photosynthetic membrane systems in which bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids are located. Under anoxic conditions, cells are capable of photolithoautotrophic growth with sulfide or sulfur as electron donor, thiosulfate may also be used. During sulfide oxidation, globules of elemental sulfur are transiently stored inside the cells. The final oxidation product is sulfate. In the presence of sulfide and bicarbonate, several simple organic substrates are photoassimilated. Facultatively chemoautotrophic or mixotrophic under micro-oxic to oxic conditions. Mesophilic bacteria with good growth at 25-35 degrees Celsius, pH 6.5 - 7.6. Principally a freshwater bacteria, although strain DSM 198 was isolated from brackish water. Strain DSM 198 is the type strain (adapted from PMID 9828415).

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated in 1961 by Chase Van Baalen from an onshore; marine mud flat sample derived from fish pens on Maguyes Island; La Parguera; Puerto Rico
isol:isolation_source: Onshore; marine mud flat sample derived from fish pens on Maguyes Island; La Parguera; Puerto Rico
proj:comments: Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002.The cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002 (formerly known as Agmenellum quadruplicatum strain PR-6) was originally isolated in 1961 by Chase Van Baalen from an onshore; marine mud flat sample derived from fish pens on Maguyes Island; La Parguera; Puerto Rico. The organism grows in brackish (euryhaline/marine) water and is unicellular but tends to form short filaments of two to four cells during exponential growth at the temperature optimum of 38oC. The cells are 1.5 to 2.5 mkm in length and lack phycoerythrin and phycoerythrocyanin. Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002 can grow heterotrophically with glycerol as substrate; has an obligate requirement for vitamin B12; and most importantly; is naturally transformable. It is among the fastest growing of all cyanobacteria; and has a doubling time of about 3.5 hours under optimal conditions (light intensity ~250 mkmol photons m-2 s-1; nitrogen source urea; 2% (v/v) CO2). The strain is extremely tolerant of high light intensities and has been grown at light intensities equivalent to two suns. This unique combination of physiological and genetic properties have long made this strain an important model system to studies of the oxygenic photosynthetic apparatus; the regulation of carbon and nitrogen metabolism; and other aspects of cyanobacterial physiology and metabolism.
secmet:antismash_types: Putative fatty acid cluster|Putative cluster|Putative saccharide cluster|Other uncategorized cluster|Siderophore cluster|Type I PKS cluster|Terpene cluster
seq:center: Penn State University, Beijing Genomic Institute, Peking University

isol:isolation_comments: Strain NATL2A is a low light-adapted ecotype of Prochlorococcus, isolated at 10 m in the North Atlantic Ocean, 38° 59? N, 40° 33? W (Garczarek et al., 2000). This strain belongs to a clade (Rocap et al., 2002) that is most numerous at a depth of about 100 m below the surface. As a group, Prochlorococcus is speculated to be the most abundant photosynthetic organism on the planet (Partensky et al 1999), and is responsible for a significant fraction of photosynthesis in the world's oceans. In the subtropical Pacific, for example, it often represents 50% of the total chlorophyll.
proj:comments: Prochlorococcus marinus strain NATL2A. This strain was collected at a depth of 10 meters in the north Atlantic Ocean.

isol:isolation_comments: microbial mat material
proj:comments: The Iheya North Knoll in the mid-Okinawa Trough is a methane-rich deep-sea hydrothermal field. To cultivate methane-oxidizing bacteria from the Iheya North field, a continuous flow-through reactor cultivation was conducted using gill tissue of Bathymodiolus japonicus as an inoculum. The enriched culture consisting mainly of methane-oxidizing bacteria was subjected to genetic analyses to investigate their metabolic characteristics.
seq:center: Department of Subsurface Geobiological Analysis and Research, Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology

proj:comments: Genus Nitratiruptor is one of the most abundant chemolithoautotrophic microorganisms associated with the deep-sea hydrothermal environments in the Okinawa Trough, Japan. To know the evolutional history of Epsilonproteobacteria especially in the acquisition of pathogenicity and widespread propagation and adaptation to various ecological niches, it is necessary to reveal the co-evolution of temperate phages and deeply branching epsilonproteobacterial lineage in more details. Here, we characterized phages induced from diverse Nitratiruptor strains, and conducted comparative genomic analyses.
seq:center: Department of Subsurface Geobiological Analysis and Research, Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology

proj:comments: Candidatus Uab amorphum is a marine bacterium with phagocytosis-like engulfment. This bacterium belongs to Plnactomycetes, however it has some eukaryotic features, e.g., amoeba-like cell form, cytoskeleton, and membrane-involved engulfment. The study goal is to understand mechanisms and evolution of such an eukaryotic feature. Particularly, we are focusing on mechanism of the phagocytosis-like engulfment.

isol:isolation_source: Thread-sail filefish (Stephanolepis cirrhifer) and black scraper (Thamnaconus modestus)
proj:comments: From 2009 to 2013, rapid-growing non tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) was isolated from thread-sail filefish (Stephanolepis cirrhifer) and black scraper (Thamnaconus modestus). This NTM have pathogenicity to these two specie of marine teleost fish. The representative strain NJB0901T is acid-fast and growth is observed following incubation for 3-5 days at 30 degrees C. Colonies can be either rough or smooth, with no pigmentation regardless of exposure to light. Based on the results of multi locus sequence typing and molecular phylogenetic analysis, the piscine isolates represent a novel species of M. chelonae-M. abscessus group mycobacteria, for which the name Mycobacterium stephanolepidis.

isol:project_name: Genome information upgrading project of cyanobacteria in the NIES collection
proj:comments: Cyanobacteria are prokaryotic organisms that perform oxygen-evolving photosynthesis. Several cyanobacteria strains have been used as a model organism in the research fields of photosynthesis, photoacclimation, bloom formation, and metabolic engineering. On the other hand, the cyanobacteria phylum comprised morphologically, physiologically and genetically diverse strains and they are broadly distributed in the terrestrial and aquatic environments. Understanding of cyanobacteria diversity via genome sequencing of the strains deposited in the culture collection is becoming a new trend. The aim of this project is to comprehensively analyze the genomes of cyanobacteria strains in the National Collection of the National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES) in Japan. In 2016, we focused on the 20 cyanobacteria strains that can form heterocyst, a thick walled differentiated cell for nitrogen fixiation. The genome size of the heterocystous cyanobacteria is relatively large (5-12M bp) and contains many repeated sequences, which make it difficult to obtain high quality genome information. We sequenced the PCR-free and the long mate pair DNA libraries of these strains using the MiSeq sequencer, and performed in silico gap closing and Sanger sequencing. The assembled genomes were annotated the manually curated annotation in the genome database Cyanobase. These data will facilitate our understanding of diversity and evolution of the molecular processes among cyanobacteria phylum. This project is supported by the National Bio Resource Project in Japan.

proj:comments: The strain Neptunomonas japonica JAMM 1380 was isolated from the sediment adjacent to sperm whale carcasses off Kagoshima, Japan, at a depth of about 230 m. This strain indicates a relationship to the symbiotic bacterial clone R46 of marine oligochaete Osedax japonicus (99.9 % identities in the sequences of 16S ribosomal RNA gene). The complete genome sequence and comparative genome analysis among Osedax symbionts will provide important insights into their evolution, physiological functions, and interactions with their host animals

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from a cultured yellowtail that succumbed to nocardiosis in Japan was determined and annotated
proj:comments: Nocardiosis caused by Nocardia seriolae is one of the major threats in the aquaculture of Seriola species (yellowtail: S. quinqueradiata, amberjack: S. dumerili and kingfish: S. lalandi) in Japan. Complete genome sequences of N. seriolae provide a powerful tool for understanding their biology, including mechanisms of their pathogenicity and their drug-resistant properties, as well as for developing new genetic and molecular approaches for disease control strategies. In this project, using Single Molecule, Real-Time (SMRT) DNA sequencing, the complete genome nucleotide sequence of N. seriolae UTF1 isolated from a yellowtail that succumbed to nocardiosis in Japan was determined and annotated.

In addition, genome information about its chemolithoautotrophy will also contribute environmental microbial ecology in hydrothermal environments

isol:world_region: Indian Ocean region§gaz:00051084<§eco:0000313>Kairei hydrothermal vent field§gaz:00002488
proj:comments: Samples used in this study were obtained by means of DSV Shinkai 6500 at the Kairei hydrothermal field (Van Dover et al.; 2001) in the Central Indian Ridge (25° 19.23′S; 70° 02.42′E). Scaly-foot snail; tentatively named ‚ÄòCrysomallon squamiferum‚Äô; was for the first in 2001. The snail lives a sedentary life at the base of black-smoker chimneys in the Kairei hydrothermal field in the Indian Ocean. The sclerites cover the sides of the foot in a roof-tile fashion. The gastropod houses densely a member of the order Thiotrichales within the cells of its greatly enlarged esophageal gland. Little is known about physiological characteristics and ecological significance of endosymbionts. We therefore performed the genome analysis on the symbiont of scaly-foot snail. The complete genome sequence and comparative genome analysis among Thiotrichales symbionts will provide important insights into their evolution; physiological functions; and interactions with their host animals

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from sea water from the Pacific Ocean is aerobic; Gram-negative; orange-pigmented and rhodopsin-containing bacterium. S1-08T was isolated from sea water samples collected from the western north Pacific Ocean (30°11’ N, 145°05’ E; depth 0 m) by the R/V Mirai (Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology [JAMSTEC]) on Feb. 9, 2010 (MR10-01 cruise). The sea water (200 μl) sample was inoculated on 1/10 strength ZoBell agar medium (0.5 g peptone, 0.1 g yeast extract, 15 g agar in 1 l of 80 % aged natural sea water) and incubated at 20 °C for 30 days. After incubation, colonies were picked and re-isolated on Marine agar 2216 (MA: Difco).

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from Pacific Ocean sea water. A pristanedegrading bacterium, strain PR4, was isolated from the Pacific Ocean south of Okinawa Island, Japan, at a depth of 1,000 m.
proj:comments: Rhodococcus erythropolis PR4 (NBRC 100887). Rhodococcus erythropolis PR4 (NBRC 100887) was isolated from Pacific Ocean sea water. It has the enzymes necessary for the degradation of different alkanes; such as pristane. PR4 shows tolerance to hydrocarbons and it is capable of producing several compounds with medical; industrial; and nutritional applications such as beta-carotenes (i.e. astaxanthin) and fatty acid-containing extracellular polysaccharides (i.e. mucoidan). PR4 strain harbors one linear plasmid; pREL1 and two circular plasmids; pREC1 and pREC2; all with sequence similarities to other Rhodococcus plasmids. Plasmid pREL1 harbors metal-resistance and alkane-degradation genes. Plasmid pREC1 encodes for a complete set of beta-oxidation enzymes of fatty acids.

Detailed genomic analyses will give further information and insight into the metabolism of archaeal species.

Members of the phylum Acidobacteria are ubiquitous in both terrestrial and oceanic environments. Thermotomaculum hydrothermale AC55 is the thermophilic bacterium isolated from a deep-sea hydrothermal field, representing Acidobacteria subdivision 10. The strain was an obligatory anaerobic heterotroph capable of fermentative growth on complex proteinaceous substances. To understand fully the metabolic potential and phylogenetic place of strain AC55, we performed whole genome analysis.

isol:isolation_comments: Isolated from vaccinated yellowtail
proj:comments: Lactococcus garvieae is a causative agent of Lactococcosis in farmed genus Seriola. In Japan, injectable and oral vaccines have been developed and commercialized to prevent Lactococcosis in yellowtail S. quinqueradiata, amberjack S. dumerili and kingfish S. lalandi. In 2012, L. garvieae-like strains were isolated from vaccinated yellowtail. These isolates were identified as L. garvieae by general bacteriological characterization, 16S rRNA sequence analysis and DNA-DNA relatedness. In general, slide agglutination test with anti-serum was used for identify of L. garvieae fish isolates. However, these isolates were not agglutination with usual anti-serum and these L. garvieae recognized to non-agglutinating L. garvieae. To investigate the genetic information of non-agglutinating L. garvieae, we report the complete genome sequence of non-agglutinating L. garvieae 122061 strain.

proj:comments: The deep-mussel Bathymodiolus septemdierum is distributed in hydrothermal vents in the Izu-Ogasawara Island-arc, Japan, owing its biomass to the functional dependence on its symbiotic association with chemoautotrophic sulfur-oxidizing bacteria. Little is known about physiological characteristics and ecological significance of endosymbionts. We therefore performed the genome analysis on the endosymbiont of Bathymodiolus septemdierum. The complete genome sequence and comparative genome analysis among sulfur-oxidizing endosymbionts will provide important insights into their evolution, physiological functions, and interactions with their host animals.
